title: Which presidential candidate will win Texas?
preds: Congrats to those who called this, I had it as a toss-up.

39% comes from 538's forecast. +3% to that comes from the transitive property applied to Trump vs Cruz, Beto vs Cruz, Biden vs Beto, Biden vs Trump as described here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1174955
Hedging. The turnout is pretty incredible right now.
Trump has a slight edge here but turnout could be his downfall.

[Postmortem two days after election: pollsters missed the massive Hispanic realignment toward GOP. Missed the Democratic collapse in Rio Grande Valley.] Seeing way too many experts who think Joe narrowly wins Texas. I'm not smarter than them, so bumping this up. I recommend the recent podcast (#55) with Dr. Richard Murray of the University of Houston here: https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/potcom/2020-politics-war-room
Support for Trump is underrepresented in polls because of the hostile political climate in the US. Trump will definitely sweep this Republican stronghold.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

DT leads by only 2%. This is totally unexpected. I was hoping to be more sure about Texas just 2 days before election, but now with such little lead, not possible.  I am giving DT chance of 65% based on Texas voting history. Going by current polls only, I would have said more like 50%

Early voting ended with Biden still ahead.  Voter turn out, however, looks like it will hit 11.5 million altogether, which was beyond what I expected. While good for democracy, this reduces the odds greatly of Biden pulling this off. In a place without universal voter registration, high turnout is good for Democrats but only up to a point.  Most likely outcome now seems to be Trump winning by a point or two.

Texas is already at 107% of their 2016 totals, and a white minority state (~42% white, non-hispanic). Expanded turnout across these types of demographics favors democrats, especially when considering the 600% growth in turnout of young voters

Looks like Biden is leading the vote count by 2 to 3 percentage points going into election day, based on this poll: https://www.uml.edu/docs/2020-Texas-Oct-Topline_tcm18-331627.pdf
With most of the remaining yet-to-vote registered voters being Republican, it will hinge on election day turnout, but Biden has a good shot to win this one. It will be very close.

Polling lead well within the margin of error for Trump right now but it's hard to see Texas flipping this year given that Biden has made no real play for it and it is historically one of the reddest states in the country. Not impossible, but unlikely.

I might post a more detailed reasoning in another post, but this should be treated as a race in toss-up territory when looking at all evidence. It's not fun to be wrong when you go against the "It's Texas, it's red" conventional wisdom, but it's the correct play here.
Updating after aggregating in some respected peer assessments.  Note that I am using the approach described by Satopaa et al 2014

Bumping this up a little, based on analysis of polling and turnout. Page 3 here breaks out difference between Texans who had already voted as of October 26th compared with those who had not yet voted: https://www.uml.edu/docs/2020-Texas-Oct-Topline_tcm18-331627.pdf  As of Oct. 26, 7,326,276 votes had been cast. As of right now, it's 8,525,424. Biden currently leads Trump by 3.2 percentage points. The estimates I'm seeing are expecting a 60% turnout rate, 10 million votes, which is extremely high by Texas standards. This would give Biden a win of less than a percentage point.  The 30% chance that Trump wins TX is based on turnout being more toward 11 million, since those final votes will skew heavily Republican. Also based on the chance of shenanigans, such as Republicans getting ballots thrown out that were dropped off by automobile: https://www.khou.com/article/news/politics/petition-challenging-drive-thru-voting-is-latest-in-list-of-election-lawsuits/285-62f426e8-d7d6-463d-afa6-336f62064eb1

Thanks to @Daveinsea for the 100% prediction, which I use as an alert that there may be some easy money to be made here. Cook says toss up. I'll go 45/55. "Texas is a state that Biden doesn't need to win, but it is clear that it's more competitive than ever. Texas' shift from Lean Republican to Toss Up shouldn't come as a surprise. Recent polling in the state — both public and private - shows a 2-4 point race. That's pretty much in line with the hotly contested 2018 Senate race in the state where Sen. Ted Cruz narrowly defeated Rep. Beto O'Rourke 51 percent to 48 percent.  A huge surge in early vote (as of October 26th, almost half of Texas' registered voters had already cast a ballot) suggests that we could see record turnout in a state that has added many new residents since 2016. That also adds a level of uncertainty to the equation.  Statewide and district level polling show Biden running strong in and around metro suburban parts of the state, but underperforming with Latino voters. In his analysis of the New York Times/Siena poll (10/20-25) of the state, the New York Times' Nate Cohn writes that "Biden has a lead of only 57 percent to 34 percent among that group, somewhat beneath most estimates of Mrs. Clinton's support among Hispanic voters four years ago. The finding broadly tracks with national surveys, which have shown Mr. Trump improving among Hispanic voters compared with his 2016 standing. Similarly, Hispanic voters in the Times/Siena poll say they backed Mrs. Clinton by a margin of 60 percent to 29 percent." But, it's also the case that we don't have a whole lot of experience with Texas as a battleground state. Neither do national pollsters. In an analysis of polling errors in 2016 and 2018, my colleague David Wasserman wrote this week that polls in the Southwest "undershot Democrats' final margin in 17 of 19 cases, including by an average of 1.4 points in 2016 and 4.2 points in 2018." https://cookpolitical.com/analysis/national/national-politics/bidens-path-270-widens-trumps-path-narrows-texas-moves-toss

"But the polls! But the polls!"
"They're better this year! Scouts honor!" https://www.forbes.com/sites/chuckdevore/2020/10/29/trump-by-a-landslide-in-texas-early-voting-numbers-are-diverging-strongly-from-the-polls/
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
As a Texan, I say, Yankee, go home. Don't think I will be the only one.  538 gives Biden a 35% of winning Texas if you assume he wins PN, Mi and WI. I'll take those odds.
Demographics suggest Trump may lose this state. It may be close.
Biden’s Path to 270 Widens, Trump’s Path Narrows, as Texas Moves to Toss Up -- Cook Political Report https://twitter.com/CookPolitical/status/1321454249323208704
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
I think Biden surprises in Texas with a narrow victory. The gap between Trump and Biden has been shrinking and Trump has done little more than cater to his base.
Been too high, not just a one-off poll where Biden is competitive

Now even in the polling averages: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/texas/ When you go with registered voters instead of likely voters, btw we’re in a high turnout scenario, Biden is ahead Hays County, by Austin, has now surpassed the 2016 vote total: https://twitter.com/redistrict/status/1320357683040571392?s=21 Something tells me these aren’t Trump voters. I’m ignoring the crowd and bumping this up. Usually I am wrong when I go against the crowd, but all indicators are that this should go for Biden. Also, the VP candidate is visiting TX in the final days which definitely means the campaign sees something: https://www.houstonchronicle.com/politics/texas/article/Kamala-Harris-coming-to-Houston-on-Friday-15673946.php
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Adjusting this down to a more realistic probability, but I just want to point out that the youth vote in Texas is massive: https://circle.tufts.edu/latest-research/absentee-and-early-voting-youth-2020-election I highly recommend this twitter thread: https://twitter.com/tbonier/status/1319471034702139394
Goes through how compared with 2018 and 2016, early voting numbers are favorable for Biden. Race should be close, but Biden has a path in Texas
Incredibly (despite rapidly changing demographics) a tight race, DT should write a new book if he somehow manages to lose Texas ... 'The Art of a Loser'
Polls have tightened over the weeks where it is anywhere from tied to Trump ahead by four. This may be a closer race than anyone thought in Texas.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

40% isn't too bold a bet, but it's higher than average.  I live in Texas and see all the local political ads. If Donald Trump is in one, it is always a Democrat trying to tar their Republican opponent as a Trump supporter. Meanwhile, the Republican senator and house and state reps never mention Trump.  To recap, in Texas, Democrats love to talk about Trump, Republicans never mention him, as if Trump were an albatross.  You can say that invoking Trump is a high variance strategy for Dems , whereas Republican incumbents  don't mention Trump as a low variance strategy.  Still, both parties view Trump as a liability for the GOP in Texas.
All chips on Biden here to redeem myself after whiffing on Bolivia. Demographics + High Turnout = Blue Texas
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Texas by 2.2 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 51.3% for trump to Biden's 45.8%.  Seven day momentum was in Biden's favor, improving his position by 0.4%.
Aggregating with my prior estimate and the synth team current thinking.  Then used an extremitization constant of 1.25.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Only 1.4% difference in the polls and also they are mixed in terms who is ahead. Race is tighter than it should be for Texas.

Adjusting this up, based on further analysis. Take a look at the polls again, but distinguish between LV and RV. Biden is ahead in RVs!
Texas has one of the highest proportions of Non-Whites in the US: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_non-Hispanic_white_population
Although Texas has a large population of rural Whites,  surburbanization, economic growth and in-migration from other states have tilted things such that now at least 40% of the non-Hispanic White population has at least a bachelor's degree: https://demographics.texas.gov/Resources/Publications/2014/2014-04-08_EducationAttainment.pdf  (This is a group that has voted more blue recently.) Texas is not a red state the way Alabama or South Carolina are. The story of Texas is one of voter suppression: http://www.electproject.org/2016g  Look how low the Texas voter turnout was in 2016 compared with other states! If Texas had turnout rates in the same proportion as other states, it would be blue. Everyone knows that. The racial demographics are about the same as California; the only reason it's not blue is that turnout has been much lower. Not this year. Turnout expectations have been completely shattered, and 1 in 10 voters is a new voter: https://www.texasmonthly.com/politics/texas-early-voting-numbers-huge/

many of the forecasters I follow here are increasing Biden's chances, so I'm edging that direction, but not as strongly. Polls / assumptions about turn out would have to be somewhat off for Texas to go blue, but that world is certainly within the realm of possibility, especially with the disparity in mail in ballots heavily favoring Democrats. Still, unless I see a shift in the polls, I think it's more likely that Texas will remain red this election.

Democrats are now in a solid lead in early voting, amid massive turnout in Democratic areas. Almost 400,000 early votes now in Houston: https://www.harrisvotes.com/Docs/Uploads/EVPA_unofficial.pdf  In Travis County (Austin), 496,000 people voted in 2016, and the county clerk expects 650,000 to have voted *before* election day: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/appeals-panel-upholds-abbotts-order-for-just-one-ballot-box-per-texas-county/2020/10/13/bc51869c-0d4d-11eb-8a35-237ef1eb2ef7_story.html

Right now Trump is ahead by 1.5 percentage points per 538.  This should be enough to give Trump a win.  Yet, Covid cases are spiking right now, and I think the next two new unemployment filing reports will be awful.  This will make the race very close.  However, people are already voting, and the above will take a few weeks to register with the public.  Also, Trump may be at his Texas floor.

It is within a percentage point and a half.  This close to the election even this small lead should give about a 68 percent of a win to Trump per Chapter 2 of the Noise and the Signal by Nate Silver.  Yet,  covid is spiking and the next two weekly new unemployment claims reports I think will be awful.  This will make it very close, but normally the advantage would normally be to Biden, not Trump as the numbers rise.  I suspect Trump may be at his floor.  Also, people are voting now so Trump is slightly favored right now.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Massive day 1 lines for the first day of early voting, and in places like Houston, 10% of the 2016 turnout was achieved in just one day! 
https://twitter.com/breaking_et/status/1316178230722920450?s=21 Trump’s polling lead in Texas is razor thin
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Lowering the Republican percentage based on commentary I received.

Looks like Carter won Texas in 1976. Maybe some day the Democratic candidate will win again with the help of immigration but not this year. Trump will win many many states by a narrower margin than will he win Texas.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Texas by 2.2 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 51.35% for trump to Biden's 45.5%. No momentum for either candidate.
Latest polls show a widening lead for Trump in Texas.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Biden is pulling the ads from Texas. He is giving up in Texas https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/05/politics/trump-ads-ohio-iowa/index.html?iid=ob_article_organicsidebar_expansion

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)
Remaining anchored to the Nate Silver probabilities.  Its a mystery to me what the impact of Covid might be on voter turnout however. I will make my mind up in the coming days and weeks.
Looked at this again and decided to make a small adjustment up after aggregating my 'synth' team's most current estimates.  Did not extremitize my final prior value.
Leaving my forecast alone for the present moment.  Will update as more info becomes available.
Giving the Dems a couple extra points here. If DJ struggling with the Rona, he's not going to inspire his base to vote.

But discounting some to 22%.

Trump has consistently polled within the margin of error in Texas.  It appears some voters are willing to split their vote not only in Texas but in other deep red states as well.  I think last night's debate performance was nothing short of horrid.  There is just no other word for it.   Trump had a Captain Queeg moment last night, actually he had an hour and a half of Captain Queeg moments.  That won't hurt him with his base but it will hurt him with white suburban women and more educated whites which are voting blocks he needs to win.  Trump cannot afford to lose any voters and he lost quite a few of them last night.

Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Texas voted Republican 10 of the past 10 elections. Trump won the state by 807k votes more than Clinton, which is about 9% of the votes. Polls are within the margin of error but give Trump a 2% lead.

The Dems have squandered a golden opportunity to seal the EC by choosing not to campaign aggressively in Texas. Trump's polling lead is growing and, while still less than 2 points according to 538, with cases decreasing and little Dem presence in the state it is unlikely to decrease before the election. Not impossible for Biden to pull an upset, but far from likely.

Midway between the aggregate and 538. Or, in other words, updating because it really would be *very surprising* if the Dems won.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Texas by 2.2 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 50.25% for trump to Biden's 45.05%.

This is very close -- electoral-vote.com [1] has it going back and forth over the last couple months based on the polls they track. Though, as @oddball8 notes [2], flipping Texas seems very unlikely, but it looks like it may be closer than usual. I am going all-in on the R. [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/texas.html
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1127732

https://www.texastribune.org/2020/09/20/supreme-court-justice-texas/
It is very close but Trump consistently polling higher.

Late to the party but should still be educational.  Ran a simple monte-carlo simulation off the RCP poll numbers and then aggregated my results with a small 'synthetic' team of fellow forecasters, using the approach of Satopaa et al, 2013.
Downgrading from 80, which seemed too bullish given some polls have them neck and neck in Texas.
538 is really bullish on Biden winning Texas; I'm going a little bit up.
Texas still leans Republican and while demographics are changing probably not going to change this vote.
The hidden clue in the this question is the word "Texas."

The Republican candidate has won every time in Texas this century, but Trump's 52.2% win in 2016 was the worst performance of a Republican candidate in Texas this century. This could be an indicator that Trump already struggled to convince Texans in 2016, despite it being the quintessential red state.  Not to sound overblown, but Trump's antics become more and more ridiculous by the day. If anything could make Texas swing, it'd be him. Nonetheless, the polls for the most part still have Trump winning in Texas, and the historical precedent still matters. I think it will be a closer result than usual in Texas, but I'd still expect Trump to win. A third party presidential candidate has not won in any state since 1968, so although it is in theory possible, that outcome would be one of the biggest upsets ever. I'm confident to discount it as an option.  https://www.270towin.com/2020-polls-biden-trump/texas/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_third-party_performances_in_United_States_presidential_elections#:~:text=The%20last%20third%2Dparty%20candidate,1996%2C%20respectively%3B%20the%20closest%20since
Senate race is the lead in Texas.
Biden's hopes have dimmed in Texas but it still won't be a blowout.
Trump will win.   Notwithstanding the inroads Democrats have made in Texas, it still remains a Republican state.

It is still a close race based on yesterday's polling. However, with numerous scandals coming out in the past week that may impact Trump's popularity, I'm switching Texas closer to a 50/50 toss-up with a slight preference for the Republican candidate due to historical trends.
Trump has consistently led in the polls here.  Current RCP avg has him up +3.5.
Recent polling has the race as tight, but a traditionally republican state in a heavily gerrymanderise country makes it unlikely for states to swing.
Updating.  Recent polls have this race within 1-2%.  I lean for the Republican unless there is a significant market decline by October 15th.

Used Nate Silver website for my anchor.  Adjusted slightly in Trump's favour as I would intuitively expect the polls to narrow as we get closer. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/texas/

Right now, Trump is trending ahead of Biden about 5-7 points, but demographics show that there is uncertainty there. Trump is 18 points ahead with men, but either behind or only very modestly ahead with all other demographics. (https://thetexan.news/latest-texas-polling-shows-trump-ahead-contentious-congressional-races/) Given that turnout is the key here, there may still be some chance that Texas flips this year, especially if typically marginalized and disenfranchised voters turn out in higher numbers.
Waiting to see what happens after RNC. https://dknation.draftkings.com/2020/8/25/21400631/joe-biden-vs-donald-trump-texas-poll-democratic-national-convention-public-policy-polling
Funny how this mirrors the 538 prediction.
Up a bit on rumours of Kang and Kodos endorsement  :)

Democrats are not actively pursuing Texas. None of the speakers at their convention are Texan politicians and they didn't choose a Texas location for the convention, though it was one of the finalists. Trump's lead is beginning to grow again, with the last 2 polls showing a 6 and 7 point lead. It is likely his initial fall was driven primarily by the surge in coronavirus cases in the state, a surge which has since begun diminishing. With 78 days before the election it is unlikely voters will vote based on the conditions dominating the past few weeks unless localities return to those levels before the ballots are cast, which is not very likely.
This race has the potential to be close, but as the polls tightening, the polls in Texas will widen in favor of Trump.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/texas/ Tight at the moment, expecting Biden to fall back a bit as time elapses.

Cornyn is winning by 7, though there is disapproval of Trump by 13, people generally vote straight ticket. But, then, Sanders was winning by double digits and Biden won. There are 358,002 Asian Indians residing in Texas which is good for Harris, not all of them will vote, or of age to vote, for Biden. There are five Asian Indians on the ballot in Texas all Democrats. Very close for now but GOP in lead because of Cornyn, not Trump. Also, the GOP is waging war against traditional voting rights such as poll tax in Florida, voter suppression, not funding the USPS, or election, and Russian software.

Realistically, Biden has very little support outside of the major metro counties.  The suburban counties are in play, but not seriously.  Heavy metro turnout could flip things, but I don't see that until 2024...if ever.
Good chances to close the gap, but probably not for demo win

My reasoning on Texas is that while the population there has become more diverse it is still not a place welcoming to the ideas of diversity and inclusion. It is possible Trump Administration bungling will result in Democrats winning but not betting on that. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-texas-idUSKCN256109
My uncertainty fits inside 25%. See also https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5798

I am originally from Texas and do think that the Ds could eventually win there given demographic shifts. However, I don't think this will be the year. It may be closer than the Rs would like, but I think they still hold here.
Traditionally a Red state, but the Democrat will seriously challenge this election, however turnout will favor Republicans.
It’s going to be close and dissatisfaction over the virus outbreak will be a factor that helps the Democrats, but Texas is not quite there
Too tight and swinging.. hard to tell at this time..
Considering that a second wave of coronavirus is likely by November, especially in Texas, purple-leaning Texas could very well go to Biden.

Texas is a huge, huge state to campaign in. Multiple media markets that are extremely expensive and a minority population that is not registered at levels required to make it as appealing to Democrats. Biden may win but it would be an upset.

Although more Democrats are moving to major Texas cities at a high rate, they are not yet at a point where they're on par with the traditionally republican voting base. Bidan is not a very motivating candidate for anyone without OMB disorder. Unless there is a significant upset that tanks Trump's approval utterly it's not going to happen. Jo Jorgeson may get some votes in Texas but will most likely be picking up Democrat stragglers and principled republicans upset with Trump's soft second amendment stance.
Texas has had a large influx of people running from high taxes. Any Democratic candidate would be swept aside because they've searched for stability...not riots.

The majority of polls predict a Trump victory.
Polls are 'naturally' biased against Trump.
Current polling suggests fairly even contest for decided voters. Expect significant amount of undecided and strong history of voting Rep.  End result likely for Trump to carry Texas.
Basing campaigns on those  who traditionally don't vote is a bad bet.  O'Rourke has shown a strong ability to increase young voters but there just aren't enough yet.

This state will still be a Republican win in 2020.  A combination of voting history and the greater interest in voting by Republican voters will still be sufficient to offset the changing demographics of the state.  Bidens selection of his V.P. will not have a significant effect on the Texas election.
Texas is becoming more purple, but it’s still Texas.  Voter suppression will ensure the Republican nominee wins
Demographics will flip this state eventually. But not this year.
It’s Texas, I think maybe in the next election it could be a swing state, but I don’t believe they have the numbers this time.
Texas appears consistently Conservative in the last 5 presidential elections. I lean significantly towards another Republican win

Texas is no guarantee for the GOP anymore, due to changed demographics. It has been trending blue this past decade, with increased numbers of non-white voters and with college-education suburbs trending blue:
1.) In 2012, Mitt Romney won by 16 points. 
2.) In 2016, Trump won by 9 points.
3.) In 2018, Ted Cruz won by 3 points.  ... and now Trump is up by less than 1 in the polling average: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/texas/ Black and Hispanic populations in Texas are similar to California at this point: https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/CA,TX/PST045219
Also, percentage of population with bachelor's degree or higher is similar -- which is a boost for Democrats under the present environment. The trends listed here have continued through 2018 and through polling today: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/education-not-income-predicted-who-would-vote-for-trump/  Some say the only thing keeping Texas red is suppressing the vote of the non-white demographics: https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/mar/02/texas-polling-sites-closures-voting
But with college-educated suburban whites trending Democratic, it looks to me like it's getting close to 50/50
Texas is a R stronghold, and mail-in voting is not encouraged as of today.
Too tight and swinging.. hard to tell at this time..
The pandemic will sway a moderate percent of the conservative voters to break ranks out of fear of another four years of mismanagement.
God and Guns carry the day deep in the heart of Texas. Might be closer than in 2018 but it will be hard for a Dem to win this state.
Polls reasonably close but as the election draws closed, Trump should put some distance between him and Biden.
The stars at night are big and bright
Biden is competitive in Texas with recent polls showing a dead heat. The next few months will determine if this is actually feasable.

Seems that the red Texas will stay, very few of the past polls and aggregation have been been within sufficient accuracy of the final result for the state.  likely red That being said these appear to be the bluest polls i observed.

While this race is quite close, with polls showing Biden with a slight lead, Texas has a long history of voting republican in presidential contest. As the demographics of the state change it will become a battleground state, but in 2020, it’s still a republican state to lose.
Easy one. Look at how many people are wearing mask in Texas. If most people are not wearing mask, then its Trump all the way...

- Looking at polls makes me feel like it is a 50%-50% race in Texas (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/texas/).
- In the 20th and 21st century, out of 30 elections, Texas has been won by Republicans 20 out of 30 times, that is 67% chance for Republicans. Even after Nixon resigned, who Trump is often compared to, by opponents and critics, Texas voted for Carter.
- Then I want to adjust my sentiment, by using the "silent majority" argument. Yes, there are many non-vocal Republicans in Texas as well as other states. The Democrats are on a roll these months, driven by covid and BLM movement. But, when it comes to voting day, in Texas that is a typical Republican stronghold, I believe there will be a re-concentration of Republicans on the ballot, that is not showing up on polls now (something like "silent majority" argument that you hear sometimes. I buy that. Republicans that would be less vocal than Democrats, it somehow makes sense to me). So I am adjusting to something like 80%-20% for Republicans.
- Finally, the crowd will be somewhat more modest in their predictions I suppose, so I want to be more extreme and gamble myself some extra Brier points :)
Dead heat now. All the you don’t want to be tied down by rules talk and name calling just might work for extremely independent Texas.

This seems like it will be a hard one for the D to win, but polls are starting to show it flopping back and forth [1,2]. I find it hard to believe that will happen, unless we are starting to see other elections in the state go to the D as well. The Senate race looked to be tied up for the R [3]. I won't start to believe Biden can take it until that lead isn't flopping back and forth and it more than a couple points.  [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/texas.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/texas/
[3] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Graphs/texas.html

Texas is Republican, always have been. Right now they are polling slightly in Biden's favor, but it is unlikely the turmoil and controversy of recent weeks will continue through the election. While the corruption and political unrest may not become any less historically relevant, it is unlikely to stick in voters minds for the next three months. Trump will slowly rise to his original levels of popularity and Biden will likely suffer the fate of all Democrats who challenge for Texas in recent history: a loss. It may be small, but it is more likely than not to happen in the end.
By November the stage is set for a Biden landslide. Texas goes Democratic.

Depends on how much the Biden campaign and 3rd parties decide to spend. I think the cost of trying to put Texas in play may be too high this year. If they allocate their resources to other swing states, Texas will most likely remain red in 2020. Biden doesn’t really need Texas to win the election, and there are more strategic states to blanket with ads.
I know JB polling well locally but a massive ask for him to get Texas ... he doesn't need to and unlikely to allocate significant resources to do so.
Depends on turnout in this Republican state.  Changing demographics like GA.  Both close to turning purple.
